node.title: Ken Griffin, head of Citadel, bid highest for a copy of the Constitution.
node.alt: Ken Griffin, right, with Andrew Ross Sorkin last week. “I intend to ensure that this copy of our Constitution will be available for all Americans and visitors to view and appreciate in our museums and other public spaces,” he said in a statement.
node.description: A group of cryptocurrency fans known as ConstitutionDAO had also bid on the document, setting off a frenzy of memes and pledges.
node.content: ["In the battle for the Constitution, the traditionalist beat out the insurgents.", "Ken Griffin, the chief executive of the hedge fund Citadel, was the winner of an auction for a rare original copy of the U.S. Constitution, Sotheby\u2019s, the host of the auction, said Friday. He beat a group of cryptocurrency fans known as ConstitutionDAO, whose bid set off a frenzy of memes, jokes and financial pledges. But ultimately they couldn\u2019t top Mr. Griffin\u2019s $43.2 million offer.", "The winning bid was more than double the $20 million the item was originally estimated to go for. Sotheby\u2019s said the sale set a record for a book, manuscript, historical document or printed text.", "\u201cThe U.S. Constitution is a sacred document that enshrines the rights of every American and all those who aspire to be,\u201d Mr. Griffin said in a statement. \u201cThat is why I intend to ensure that this copy of our Constitution will be available for all Americans and visitors to view and appreciate in our museums and other public spaces.\u201d", "The first museum to display this copy of the Constitution will be Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art in Bentonville, Ark., which was founded by the Walmart heiress Alice Walton.", "\u201cWe are honored to exhibit one of the most important documents in our nation\u2019s history from our location in the heartland of America,\u201d the chair of the museum\u2019s board, Olivia Walton, said in a statement.", "Mr. Griffin, who has a net worth of about $21 billion, according to Forbes, is accustomed to breaking records. He broke a real estate record in 2019 when he closed on his purchase of a Manhattan penthouse at 220 Central Park South for $238 million.", "He also has been forthcoming about his about concerns regarding cryptocurrency. \u201cI worry that some of this passion has been misplaced when it comes to cryptocurrencies,\u201d he told the New York Times journalist Andrew Ross Sorkin at the DealBook conference earlier this month."]
